unit_learning_outcomes.description: Evaluate relationships between technology, media practices, and cultures.
Demonstrate academic communication and disciplinary knowledge skills in different media and genres.
Assess the historical and technological development of present-day media forms.
Evaluate critical debates and apply media studies theories.
Formulate arguments and creative works based on appropriate research and academic sources.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Completing Before and After Class Activities
Completing set readings for the unit.

assessments.description: Students will create their own blog and make five posts throughout the term. In Week 1, teachers will assist students in creating a Wordpress blog, and making their first post, using images, videos and hyperlinks. This first post will not be marked. In Weeks 2, 3, 4 and 5, students will be given a chance to workshop ideas in groups and they will then individually create blog posts of 250 words. This is an individual task. Further information and marking criteria is available in iLearn. Feedback will be provided in class within a week of submission and marks will be available in Gradebook. If students fail to create any of the blog posts, they should refer to the Special Consideration policy.

In Week 6, during Lessons 1 and 2, each student will present their Video Project in class. The presentation is worth 10% of the overall mark for the unit. In Week 6, Lesson 3, students are to write a reflection on their Video Project. Students will be given 30 minutes in class to write two paragraphs in response to questions provided by the teacher. The written reflection is worth 10% of the overall mark for the unit. This assignment encourages students to reflect on the suitability and scope of their video project with respect to its relevance to the unit. A good reflection will summarize the best aspects of the project while also outlining what could have been improved. Responses should focus on the research and the creative process of the project rather than on personal issues faced. As students will view/listen to other students’ work in Lessons 1 and 2 in week 6, they will be required to include references to some positive aspects of other students' work, and how they might have integrated these ideas into their own work.

Students will undertake a video research project relating an academic theory of their choice to a technology/case study of their choice. Building on the topics and theories established in their blogs and other topics discussed in the unit, students will analyse and critically evaluate the selected digital media technology/case study using the chosen theory. Students will make a video to communicate their analysis and evaluation. Students may choose a platform such as YouTube or Vimeo, but it is the student’s responsibility to make sure that the project can be accessed by staff (i.e. it should not be password protected or private). Videos should have a duration of no more than 4 minutes. A fully referenced transcript/script of the video, including a hyperlink to the video should be submitted to Turnitin by the deadline. This is an individual task. Additional information and a marking rubric are available on iLearn. Feedback will be provided via Feedback Studio in iLearn.

data.description: At work and in our personal lives we navigate complex, ever-changing and increasingly capable digital technologies, each with their own affordances, cultural norms, and potential hazards. This unit introduces students to key ideas and contemporary debates in digital media studies. It poses questions about the history of technological change, how we create and consume digital media, what happens to our online information, and the promises and risks related to new technologies. Through class discussions, key texts, multimedia, and lesson content, students have the opportunity to engage with topics such as online identity, artificial intelligence, digital labour, participatory culture, activism, digital games, and surveillance. Through these activities, students will develop capacities to critically assess how technologies are shaped and how they shape us. Additionally, students will undertake self-directed research involving hands-on digital media production. This unit is interdisciplinary in scope, with an emphasis on innovative digital media forms and practices.
data.title: Media Technologies
